JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev
TEXT: The applicants , Ms Lidiya Aleksandrovna Podrugina and Mr PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in the town of Petrozavodsk in GPE . They were represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON PERSON , the former Representative of GPE at ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicants sought judicial recognition of the fact that they had been prisoners of war during World War II . Such a declaration was a precondition for claiming a statutory DATE allowance from the ORG . The ORG was represented by a local ORG in those proceedings .

By judgment of DATE , the ORG of GPE granted the applicants’ claim . The court found that at the time the applicants had been forced to work and had not been allowed to leave the territory of the village .

On an unspecified date , the President of ORG lodged a request for supervisory review of the above judgment . On DATE the Presidium of ORG granted his request , quashed the judgment and rejected the ORG claims . The ORG court found that in the absence of documentary evidence , including archive sources , or other evidence the above circumstances were insufficient for concluding that the village had served as a concentration camp . The court concluded that the applicants could not be considered as prisoners of war . The applicants were not present at the supervisory review hearing .

From DATE to DATE the applicants received the allowance , varying from CARDINAL to MONEY per month . After the annulment of the judgment in their favour , they were not required to reimburse the monies received during that period .
On DATE ORG ( the “ Authority ” ) , a specialised ORG agency , took over responsibility for making allowance payments .

In DATE the applicants brought new proceedings before ORG asking for a judicial confirmation of the fact that DATE they had been living in a village occupied by ORG and thus indeed been prisoners of war . The ORG was represented by ORG in those proceedings .

By judgments of DATE and DATE , ORG granted the second and first ORG claims respectively . In PERSON PERSON ’s case , the court heard CARDINAL persons who had resided at the time in the same village , and had regard to an expert opinion .

No appeal was lodged and the above judgments became final . On the basis of those judgments , on unspecified dates the applicants applied to ORG for a statutory allowance , which they subsequently received until DATE and DATE respectively .

In DATE ORG applied for supervisory review of the judgments of CARDINAL DATE and DATE , contending that it had not been aware of them in good time and thus could not request their supervisory review within the statutory period of DATE . The ORG contended that the above judgments concerned the same matter that had already been determined in DATE proceedings .

By a decision of DATE , ORG extended the timelimit for lodging of the ORG ’s request for supervisory review . The court accepted the ORG ’s argument that it had learnt about the DATE proceedings on DATE , when ORG had provided it with the lists of persons no longer entitled to an allowance . ORG and not the ORG had been involved in the DATE proceedings .

On DATE the Presidium of ORG of GPE quashed the judgment of DATE and discontinued the proceedings . The court found that the matter had already been examined in DATE and had been finally determined by the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . Apparently , the first applicant was not present at the supervisory - instance hearing and obtained a copy of its ruling on an unspecified date . According to the Government , a copy of the supervisory review ruling was dispatched to her on DATE .
The applicant was not required to reimburse the monies received in DATE and DATE .

By a decision of DATE , ORG refused to extend the time - limit for bringing supervisory review proceedings . The court found that the ORG should have been aware of the judgment of DATE since it had been making regular payments to the applicant on that basis ; a copy of that judgment had been in the applicant ’s pension file since DATE . Hence , the ORG could have challenged the judgment by way of supervisory review within the DATE time - limit .

On DATE ORG of GPE quashed the decision of DATE and remitted the matter to ORG . It held that the ORG had learnt about the relevant fact , namely the existence of CARDINAL contradictory judgments ( dated DATE and DATE ) , only in DATE .
On DATE ORG extended the time - limit for lodging of the NORP request for supervisory review . The applicant did not appeal .

On DATE the Presidium of ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and discontinued the proceedings . The court found that the matter had already been examined in DATE and had been finally determined by the judgment of CARDINAL DATE .
The applicant was not required to reimburse the monies received in DATE and DATE .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that a judge should refuse to deal with a claim if there is a final judgment between the same parties on the same subject - matter and on the same legal grounds ( по тем же основаниям ) . In such a situation , a claimant can not bring new proceedings against the same respondent in relation to the same subject - matter and on the same legal grounds .

Under LAW , judicial decisions that have become legally binding , with the exception of judicial decisions by the Presidium of ORG of GPE , may be appealed against to a court exercising supervisory review , by parties to the case and by other persons whose rights or legal interests have been adversely affected by the judicial decisions concerned ( § CARDINAL ) . ORG decisions may be appealed against to a court exercising supervisory review within DATE after they became legally binding ( § CARDINAL ) . By its ruling of CARDINAL DATE , ORG interpreted LAW as allowing the above - mentioned persons to apply for supervisory review only after having exhausted all available ordinary appeals .
